key_points: Norm Macdonald, famed for his role on 'Saturday Night Live' and as the host of 'Weekend Update', has died at age 61.
Macdonald's death was due to a nine-year private battle with cancer.
He began his career writing for 'Roseanne', joined 'SNL' in 1993, and was known for his unique comedic voice.
Macdonald was removed from the 'Weekend Update' desk in 1998, a decision he attributed to NBC West Coast president Don Ohlmeyer's disapproval of his O.J. Simpson jokes.
'SNL' issued a statement mourning the loss of Macdonald, highlighting his unflinching integrity and humor.
Macdonald's humor often tackled serious subjects like cancer, reflecting his perspective on life and death.
Throughout his career, Macdonald starred in 'The Norm Show', had a recurring role on 'The Middle', and appeared on late-night shows, notably with David Letterman and Conan O'Brien.
Tributes poured in from celebrities like David Letterman, Conan O'Brien, and Seth Rogen, all emphasizing his unparalleled talent in comedy.
Macdonald was born in Quebec City, Canada, was once married, and leaves behind an adult son, Dylan Macdonald.
His death is mourned by many in the comedy and entertainment world, reflecting on his legacy as a 'comedy genius'.
